awd_titl_txt: Scanning Electrochemical Microscopy and Ultramicroelectrode Studies of Electrocatalysis at Nanoparticle Ensembles of Microdimensions and at Single Nanoparticles
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Cynthia Zoski of New Mexico State University is studying electrocatalysis at finite nanoparticle ensembles and single nanoparticles on conducting surfaces of ultramicrodimensions where kinetic investigations are carried out under high mass transport conditions. Nanoparticles are an important part of the overall catalyst design in energy devices such as fuel and solar cells. These studies provide wide-ranging knowledge on the relationship between nanoparticle size, distribution, and catalytic activity. These studies also address a key issue in electrocatalysis regarding the nature of intermediates and adsorbed species on a catalyst surface while the electrode reaction occurs, which aid in diagnosis of reaction mechanisms, with relevance to molecular recognition, sensing, and to infectious diseases where biofilm integrity and the relationship to quorum sensing and bacteria micro-colonies are of interest. Broader impacts also include training of post-doctoral fellows and graduate students in multi-disciplinary scientific research in areas of national importance, and developing a new course in advanced electrochemical techniques which targets post-doctoral fellows, graduate and senior undergraduate students from chemistry, chemical engineering, physics, and biology.

This project focuses on electrocatalysis at nanoparticle ensembles and single nanoparticles, development of simulations to describe their behavior, fabrication and analysis of ensemble and single nanoparticle electrodes through single nanoparticle collisions at ultramicroelectrodes, and the use of scanning electrochemical microscopy to study the kinetics and nature of the reactivity of electrogenerated oxide films and those adsorbed as a result of an electrocatalytic reaction.  The collision approach to nanoparticle electrodes allows control over the number of nanoparticles on a surface, flexibility in selection of the electrode material and nanoparticle type (e.g. metallic, core shell, alloy) and size, and a direct comparison between finite ensemble and single nanoparticle kinetics at the same electrode. The shape of collision transients provides insight into the microscopic details of the nature of nanoparticle interaction with an electrode and the kinetics of electrocatalytic reactions such as oxygen reduction at single nanoparticles.  Using transient surface interrogation scanning electrochemical microscopy to study the nature and reactivity of oxide films overcomes the difficulties in traditional electrochemical experiments where the working electrode itself is used to find intermediates and the response is convoluted with the current from the electrolysis and capacitive charge.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This proposal addressed electrocatalysis at nanoparticle (NP) ensembles of ultramicro-dimensions and at single NPs, development of simulations to describe their behavior, and fabrication through NP collisions and electrodeposition at ultramicroelectrode (UME) surfaces. The UME size permitted electrocatalytic investigations to be carried out under diffusion-controlled steady-state conditions and a comparison between ensemble and single NP measurements to be made.  

Platinum (Pt) NP collisions were detected by a new electrocatalytic amplification technique and atomic force microscopy (AFM) imaging to provide information about NP collision frequency, adsorption, and random distribution on a gold UME surface. Dynamic light scattering measurements demonstrated that Pt NP aggregation was decreased in solutions of low electrolyte concentration and had the least impact on NP collision frequency. Smaller, uniform current steps when NPs collide on a UME surface were found to be indicative of NPs of metallic radii in agreement with those determined by transmission electron microscopy (TEM).  AFM imaging showed good agreement between the number of NPs imaged on a UME surface and the number of NP collisions that led to their adsorption, a spherical NP shape with a metallic radius size distribution comparable to that determined by TEM, and a random NP distribution on the UME surface. The Pt NP electroactive surface area demonstrated that all NPs on the UME surface after collision were attached and electrochemically active. Collectively, these results demonstrated for the first time that every NP collision was successful and occurred through a sticking mechanism. Thus, NP collision experiments could be used to prepare small NP ensembles on a UME (UME-NPEs). In electrocatalysis, such UME-NPEs bridge the gap between classical ensemble studies on large platforms and isolated single NP investigations. 

Since a significant background current for electrocatalytic reactions occurred on a gold surface, glass-insulated ultramicrometer carbon fiber electrodes (CF UMEs) were developed to support a single NP and NP ensembles in electrocatalytic investigations.  Pt NP collision experiments using electrocatalytic ampliﬁcation were used to deposit an exact number of Pt NPs on a CF UME surface. CF surface roughness signiﬁcantly decreased the sticking of Pt NPs on the CF surface. This roughness was decreased through judicious polishing which led to good agreement between experimental and theoretical NP collision frequencies on a CF UME surface, and fabrication of NP ensembles of UME dimensions (UME−NPE) and single-nanoparticle UMEs (SNP−UME) was accomplished. These electrodes were used to record steady-state voltammograms (SSVs) for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) in acidic media.  A Volmer-Tafel-Heyrovsky (VTH) kinetic model considering simultaneous occurrence of elementary steps and mass transport eﬀects was developed and used to interpret experimental HER SSVs. 

Experiments were performed on a range of single Pt NPs electrodeposited on a CF UME. Pt atomic cluster behavior was also examined by using the same CF UME to electrodeposit a single Pt atomic cluster. HER kinetics in acidic media were investigated on these single Pt NPs and atomic clusters and compared to that found for bulk Pt using our VTH model to extract kinetic information from each experimental SSV.  Larger Pt NPs approached bulk Pt behavior and followed the VT mechanism where a limiting current was reached at low overpotential. For smaller Pt NPs, kinetic behavior decreased with decreasing NP size compared to bulk Pt and the HER in acidic media followed the VH mechanism where the limiting current was observed at larger overpotentials than observed for bulk Pt and larger NPs. From all the single Pt NPs electrodeposited on a CF UME, the least active size was the atomic cluster. In single Pt NP experiments, the current response is dominated by kinetics and this facilitated observation of a current?potential response involving two distinctive waves which signaled a transition from VT to VH behavior in the VHT mechanism. In our experiments, this transition showed for the first time that at a single Pt NP of a particular size the HER in acidic media is controlled by the VHT mechanism. 

This project pushed the boundaries of our understanding of electrocatalytic and electrodeposition fundamentals and principles. It provided a new paradigm for testing electrocatalyst structure and function relationships and provided new insights into these fundamental questions. In terms of electrocatalysis, the catalytic properties of nanostructures can be vastly different from properties of bulk metals. If one can understand these differences by building catalysts NP by NP, insight can be gained into catalytic mechanisms. NPs are an important part of the overall catalyst design in energy devices such as fuel and solar cells. These studies provided wide ranging knowledge on the relationship between NP size, distribution, and catalytic activity.  The research in this project had an impact on graduate student and postdoctoral fellow training in electrochemical fundamentals, both experimentally and in electrochemical modelling, with extensions to material synthesis and characterization, development of writing and presentation skills, and exposure to competing for research and travel resources.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 01/18/2021
Modified by: Cynthia G Zoski
